I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will help the Government of Mongolia use information and 
communication technology (ICT) tools to improve urban transport services in Ulaanbaatar, the 
capital of Mongolia.1 The TA supports the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed Urban 
Transport  Development  Project2 and  is  financed  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund. The municipal government of Ulaanbaatar (MGU) requested ADB 
assistance to develop the policies, strategy, and technical specifications and to advise on 
appropriate technical solutions for ICT system installation. ADB undertook a fact-finding mission 
in October 2009 and an understanding was reached with the Ministry of Finance and MGU, the 
executing agency, on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, costs and financing, implementation 
arrangements,  and  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Mongolia has experienced rapid urbanization over the last decade—more than 60% of 
the  country’s  population  currently  resides  in  Ulaanbaatar.  Serious  urban  development 
challenges now face Ulaanbaatar, including insufficient transport infrastructure and poor quality 
of public transport services and management. Investments in urban transport infrastructure, 
management, quality of services, and road safety have significantly lagged behind the pace of 
urbanization. As a result, the city is suffering from heavy road congestion, insufficient traffic 
management,  poor  safety  conditions,  and  a  weak  public  transport  system.  These  factors 
contribute to economic inefficiency because of increased trip times, excessive fuel use, and 
poor air quality, which all diminish the quality of life. Without a viable public transport system, 
Ulaanbaatar will soon experience even more serious traffic congestion which will negatively 
affect economic development and quality of life.  
 
3.  Efficient  public  transport  management  institutions  with  clear  mandates  and  strong 
capacity  are  required  to  implement  investments,  attract  financing,  coordinate  among 
stakeholders, and regulate service providers. The institutional capacity of MGU needs to be 
improved  with  regard  to  (i)  development,  implementation,  and  enforcement  of  the  urban 
transport policy and strategy; (ii) long-term investment planning, capital budgeting, and financial 
management; and (iii) the design and management of urban transport projects financed by 
international development partners and private sector investors.  
 
4.  Financial management of the public transport sector is one of the key areas requiring 
urgent  assistance.  Bus  fares  have  not  been  increased  since  1999  while  fuel  costs  have 
increased more than five times during the same period. The municipal budget subsidizes about 
42% of the bus companies’ annual costs, but the mechanism for allocating subsidies does not 
account for actual passenger ridership and is inefficient. Bus operators do not have the financial 
resources to renew and expand their bus fleet and provide adequate transportation services. 
Interaction among the different modes of public transport is far from optimal. More than 20% of 
the  city’s  budget  is  spent  on  subsidizing  the  bus  expenditures  of  elderly  people,  military 
personnel, and students. The bus fare compensation system is inefficient because the amount 
of  compensation  is  based  on  assumptions  of  passenger  flow  and  does  not  reflect  actual

passenger numbers. This is exacerbated by illegal free riders using copied or fake identification 
documents. In addition, high levels of spending on public transport subsidies crowd out limited 
resources  from  other  important  city  budget  priorities  such  as  education  and  public  health 
programs. Thus, improving the efficiency and management of the public transport system would 
bring wide-ranging benefits in multiple sectors in Ulaanbaatar. The success and sustainability of 
the proposed Urban Transport Development Project largely depends on effectively addressing 
the  inefficient  revenue  collection  and  passenger  subsidy  systems  and  the  uncoordinated 
operating environment of the existing public transport system. The TA will build on the ongoing 
technical  assistance  to  Mongolia  for  Preparing  The  Urban  Transport  Development  Project 
(footnote 2) and ensure that (i) the above issues are addressed in detail, (ii) the cost estimates 
for the proposed ICT investments under the Urban Transport Development Project are accurate 
and financially viable, and (iii) a well-conceived plan for implementing these improvements is in 
place before the Urban Transport Development Project is implemented. 
 
5.  Urban sector development, including urban transport infrastructure and services, is one 
of  the  key  sectors  for  ADB  assistance  in  Mongolia.  ADB  has  provided  support  to  the 
government  for  urban  sector  development  since  1998.  The  Mongolia  country  operations 
business plan for 2009–20123 includes the Urban Transport Development Project in the 2011 
pipeline. The TA will help the project employ integrated ICT solutions to improve public transport 
management  in  Ulaanbaatar.  The  proposed  TA  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  urban  development 
strategy and road map for the country as well as the sustainable transport action plan, which 
aims to address transport needs and provide support to the transport sector in developing 
member  countries  and  thereby  reduce  adverse  environmental  and  social  externalities 
associated with transport.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
6.  The  TA  will  introduce  integrated  circuit  card  (ICC)  ticketing  and  automatic  vehicle 
location (AVL) systems that will improve the quality, efficiency, and transparency of the public 
transport sector. The systems will (i) establish a transparent and accountable ICT system for 
passenger ticketing based on a smart-card system; (ii) optimize use of resources by eliminating 
illegal free riding; (iii) install an efficient ICT-based financial management system; and (iv) 
rationalize bus routing, dispatching, and scheduling based on actual passenger demand and 
observed travel patterns. The proposed AVL system, which will be based on global positioning 
system technology, will help the public transport management body to (i) locate buses en route 
in real time, (ii) automatically detect deviations from schedule and allow operators to respond to 
deviations by holding buses or dispatching additional buses, (iii) develop and implement more 
efficient bus operating schedules, and (iv) transmit real-time information about bus locations to 
passengers  and  bus  operators.  Introducing  these  systems  requires  careful  planning  and 
meticulous preparatory work, including (i) establishment of a system management body, (ii) 
development of a financing mechanism, (iii) integration of the fare collection system of multiple 
bus operators, (iv) design of bus passenger services based on bus location data, and (v) 
development of a staged implementation program. 
  
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact of the TA is improved quality of public transport services in Ulaanbaatar. The 
outcome of the TA is improved capacity of MGU to render public transport services using up-to-

3
date ICT applications. The TA will help the government and MGU modernize public transport 
operations through preparatory works for the introduction of ICC ticketing and AVL systems.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The TA will improve the public transport management capacity of MGU through the 
introduction of management tools-based ICT. The TA will (i) develop a policy framework for the 
introduction of new ICT systems in the public transport sector, (ii) develop a strategy for ICC 
ticketing and AVL systems, (iii) design an organizational structure and implementation plan for 
system  installation  and  operation,  (iv)  prepare  the  technical  design  and  detailed  tender 
documentation for the ICC ticketing and AVL systems, (v) assess and develop the system 
financial analysis and investment funding scheme, and (vi) provide the project management and 
consulting services. The TA will have the following outputs:  
 
9.  Policy framework for introduction of new ICT systems in the public transport 
sector. The policy framework will (i) define the objectives of introducing ICC ticketing and AVL 
systems; (ii) develop a foundation for introducing alternative fare structures (e.g., zonal and 
distance-based fares) and analyze the impact of such changes on the sector fare revenue, 
ridership, and cost burdens on riders by income; (iii) assess the possibility for introducing 
promotional and transfer discounts using the ICC ticketing system; (iv) develop a code of rules 
and procedures for bus operators participating in the ICC ticketing system; and (v) develop a 
policy framework for an ICC ticketing system, including regulatory and institutional requirements 
and responsibilities based on consultation with government agencies and other stakeholders. 
 
10.  Strategy for ICC ticketing and AVL systems. The TA will (i) review the findings and 
recommendations  with  respect  to  ICC  ticketing  and  AVL  systems  derived  from  the  ADB-
financed TA to prepare the Urban Transport Development Project in Ulaanbaatar (footnote 2); (ii) 
prepare an implementation plan for the ICC ticketing system across multiple bus operators, and 
design an efficient cash flow mechanism, and operation and maintenance system; (iii) develop a 
strategy for staged introduction of these systems to large and small size buses; (iv) analyze the 
risks that may hamper the introduction of a consolidated bus fare collection and distribution 
system and formulate countermeasures to overcome them; (v) undertake economic cost and 
benefit analysis of introducing the systems and analyze the distribution of costs and benefits to 
bus operators, passengers, and the public transport administration of the city; and (vi) study bus 
passengers’  attitude  and  demand  for  bus  location  information  and  formulate  methods  to 
disseminate real-time bus location information.   
 
11.  Organizational  structure  and  implementation  plan.  The  TA  will  (i)  develop  an 
organizational structure for management and operation of the systems that will assess a variety 
of options, including direct management by the Public Transport Department of MGU, entering 
into a public–private partnership, and outsourcing to a private sector company; (ii) define the 
role and responsibilities of organizations that manage or operate these systems; (iii) develop the 
operational procedures of the ICC ticketing and AVL systems, including data flow and financial 
management procedures; (iv) develop a monitoring and auditing mechanism for these systems; 
(v) develop a system of staffing and resource requirements for the managing organization; and 
(vi)  define  and  prepare  drafts  of  the  requirements  for  regulatory  and  legislative  measures 
required for the introduction and administration of these systems. 
 
12.  Technical design and detailed tender document preparation for the ICC ticketing 
and AVL systems. The TA will (i) define the procurement procedure, including the type of 
tender, indicative schedule, and scope of works to be covered by the contract; (ii) develop the

4   
system configuration, system functions, data processing and structure, anti-fraud mechanism, 
and operational procedures for the ICC ticketing system; (iii) develop the system configuration, 
system functions, data flow, data processing, database structure, human–machine interface, 
and bus information dissemination arrangement of the AVL system; (iv) develop functional 
specifications for the equipment comprising ICC ticketing and AVL systems that will be vendor-
independent  and  will  promote  transparent  competitive  bidding;  (v)  prepare  international 
competitive  bidding  tender  documents  for  procurement  and  installation  of  the  systems  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time); and 
(vi) develop tender evaluation criteria and tendering schedules. 
 
13.  Financial analysis and investment funding scheme. The TA will (i) prepare cost 
estimates for equipment and facilities and the ongoing operation and maintenance costs for the 
introduction and expansion of both systems; (ii) undertake cash flow analysis and estimate the 
amount of revolving funds required for the ICC ticketing system; (iii) develop the project funding 
structure that will combine government and private financing, and international development 
assistance sources; and (iv) analyze the impact of various fare structures and fare level options 
on the bus operators. 
 
14.  Project  management  and  consulting  services  structure. The TA will (i) prepare 
detailed terms of reference for project management services by management consultants to be 
retained for the implementation of the ICC ticketing and AVL systems; (ii) define the scope of 
services to be rendered by the management consultants, including review of the outputs of the 
consulting services, review of the strategic approach and implementation program, review and 
finalization of  the  tender  documents,  assistance  to  MGU  during  the  tender  and  contractor 
selection  process,  supervision  of  the  procurement  process,  acceptance  testing  and 
commissioning, and advising MGU on any project-related issues; (iii) specify the qualification 
and experience requirements for project management services; (iv) prepare cost estimates for 
implementation of the ICT component of the ensuing Urban Transport Development Project that 
ADB plans to finance in 2011; and (v) prepare the draft contract for recruitment of project 
management consultants. 
 
15.  Technical note. The TA will summarize innovative technical, financial, and managerial 
solutions, processes, and results of the ICC ticketing and AVL system design and installation in 
a technical note. The technical note will be presented during workshops to the government and 
other project stakeholders.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000 equivalent of which $500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
and administered by ADB. The government will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent in 
kind to cover counterpart costs and services including counterpart staff, office space, furniture, 
administrative  support  services,  and  telephone  and  internet  lines.  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The  TA  has  been  conceptualized  in  close  cooperation  and  coordination  with  the 
government, MGU, and a project steering committee chaired by the mayor of Ulaanbaatar and 
comprising  representatives  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance;  Ministry  of  Environment;  Ministry  of 
Roads, Transportation, Construction and Urban Development; and traffic police. The TA will be

5
implemented over 6 months from 1 September 2010 to 28 February 2011. ADB will engage an 
international consulting firm using simplified technical proposal procedures and the quality- and 
cost-based selection method based on the quality–cost ratio of 80:20 in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The TA will 
engage 15 person-months of international consulting services with expertise in ICT, public 
transport  management,  institutional  development,  financial  management,  procurement  and 
tendering, and cost accounting; and 30 person-months of national consulting services with 
expertise  in  ICT,  public  transport  management,  cost  accounting,  engineering  design,  and 
graphics. The outline terms of reference for the consulting services are in Appendix 3. The 
government will provide an office, furniture, telephone and internet lines, and support of relevant 
MGU  staff.  TA  equipment  will  be  procured  by  the  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines, and will be retained by MGU upon TA completion. The proceeds of the 
TA will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The expected impact, outcome, output, and activities of the TA will be monitored through 
ADB review missions and reports to be produced during the TA. The inception report will be 
submitted within 1 month after consultants are mobilized, the interim report within 3 months after 
commencement of services, the draft final report at the end of month 5, and the final report 
within  1 month  after  receiving  comments  on  the  draft  final  report.  The  TA  will  produce  a 
technical note and service report that will include description of innovative technologies and 
approaches used for the system design, implementation, and management and these will be 
disseminated through publication, workshops, and seminars. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Public Transport Information and Communication Technology, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will help the Government of Mongolia and the municipal 
government  of  Ulaanbaatar  (MGU)  improve  the  quality  of  public  transport  services  and 
management through preparatory works for introducing integrated circuit card (ICC) ticketing 
and automatic vehicle location (AVL) systems. ICC ticketing and AVL systems are important 
tools for efficient management of the public transport system in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of 
Mongolia.1  
 
B.  Tasks 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months. Key activities of the consultants are to 
produce the following outputs: (i) a policy framework for introduction of the ICC ticketing and 
AVL systems; (ii) a strategy for systems development, installation, and operation; (iii) system 
design and tender document preparation; (iv) financial analysis and funding scheme; (v) system 
organizational  structure  and  implementation  plan;  and  (vi)  project  management  consulting 
services. 
 
3.  The inputs of consulting services will focus on, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following tasks. 
 
1.  Policy Framework for ICC Ticketing and AVL Systems 
 
4.  The  consultants  will  (i)  define  the  objectives  of  introducing  ICC  ticketing  and  AVL 
systems; (ii) assess the options and develop a framework for introducing alternative bus fare 
structures, including zonal and distance-based fare systems, and analyze the impact of such 
changes on the bus sector fare revenue, ridership, and the financial burden on riders, especially 
the poor; (iii) assess the possibility of introducing promotional and transfer discounts based on 
the ICC ticketing system; (iv) develop a code of rules and procedures for bus operators for 
participation in the ICC ticketing and AVL systems; and (v) prepare a policy framework and brief 
for ICC ticketing that includes regulatory and institutional requirements and responsibilities 
based on consultation with government agencies and other stakeholders. 
 
2.  Strategy for Development, Installation, and Operation of the Systems 
 
5.  The consultants will (i) review the findings and recommendations concerning the ICC 
ticketing  and  AVL  systems  derived  during  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-funded  TA  to 
prepare the Urban Transport Development Project in Ulaanbaatar (footnote 1); (ii) prepare the 
strategy and action plans for development, installation, and operation of the ICC ticketing and 
AVL systems, including consolidation of the ICC ticketing system of multiple bus operators, 
establishment of a payment clearinghouse, and operation and maintenance organization; (iii) 
formulate  the  strategy  for  introducing  these  systems  initially  to  large  buses  and  then  to 
minibuses;  (iv)  identify  the  hurdles  and  potential  technical  pitfalls  that  might  hamper  the 
introduction of a consolidated bus fare collection and distribution system and formulate a system 
of countermeasures to overcome them; (v) identify and quantify, to the extent possible, the

benefits, costs, and financial impacts of the ICC ticketing and AVL systems to bus operators, 
bus passengers, and public transport administration; (vi) study the bus passengers’ attitude and 
demand  for  bus  location  information  and  formulate  a  way  to  disseminate  bus  location 
information; (vii) survey the willingness of passengers to use stored value cards and identify 
best strategies for promoting the ICC ticketing card adoption; and (viii) identify the main travel 
patterns to obtain more accurate information on the financial impacts of distance-based fares.   
 
3.  System Design and Tender Document Preparation 
 
6.  The consultants will (i) design the ICC ticketing and AVL systems; (ii) prepare the 
required tender documents; (iii) define the most feasible procurement procedures, including the 
type of tender, indicative schedule, and scope of works covered by the tendered contract; 
(iv) study the system configuration options, including the integrated system of ICC ticketing and 
AVL  systems;  (v)  determine  the  system  configuration,  system  functions,  data  processing, 
database structure, anti-fraud mechanism, and operation procedure of the ICC ticketing system; 
(vi) determine the system configuration, system functions, data flow, data processing, database 
structure, human–machine interface, and bus information dissemination arrangement of the 
automatic bus location system; (vii) prepare vendor-independent functional specification of the 
equipment comprising ICC ticketing and AVL systems that will promote and ensure transparent 
competitive  bidding;  (viii)  prepare  tender  documents  required  for  international  competitive 
bidding for the procurement and installation of the systems in accordance with relevant ADB 
procurement guidelines; and (ix) develop tender evaluation criteria and the tendering schedule. 
 
4.  Financial Analysis and Investment Funding Scheme 
 
7.  The  consultants  will  (i)  prepare  the  cost  estimates  for  the  initial  capital  outlay  and 
operation and maintenance costs for the systems; (ii) prepare the cash flow analysis and 
estimate the amount of revolving fund required for the ICC ticketing system; (iii) develop the 
scheme to fund the project, which may include the government budget, private financing, and 
official development assistance; and (iv) analyze the impact of various fare structures and fare 
level options for bus operators and consider the financial impacts on passengers, especially the 
poor. 
 
5.  Organizational Set-Up, and Business Operation and Implementation Plan 
 
8.  The consultants will (i) develop an organizational structure for system management and 
operation, considering various options for the management body—such as direct management 
by the Public Transport Department of MGU, public–private partnership, and outsourcing to the 
private entity; (ii) define the role and responsibility of the organizations that manage or operate 
the systems; (iii) develop the operational procedure of the ICC ticketing system, including the 
data flow and cash handling procedures; (iv) develop the monitoring and auditing mechanism 
that supervises the ICC ticketing system; (v) prepare staffing and resource requirements for the 
managing organization; (vi) prepare business operation and implementation plans for (a) the 
ICC  ticketing,  and  (b)  AVL  systems;  and  (vii)  identify  the  necessity  of  any  regulatory  or 
legislative measures to be made in connection with the introduction and administration of the 
systems and prepare the required draft legal documentation. 
 
6.  Project Management Consulting Services 
 
9.  The consultants will (i) prepare detailed terms of reference for project management 
services by management consultants to be retained for implementation of the ICC ticketing and

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
AVL systems; (ii) define the services to be rendered by management consultants, which will 
include the review of outputs of the consulting services defined in this TA, review of the strategic 
approach  and  implementation  program,  review  and  finalization  of  the  tender  documents, 
assistance  to  MGU,  the  TA  executing  agency,  during  the  tender  and  contractor  selection 
process, supervision of the procurement process, acceptance testing and commissioning, and 
advising  MGU  on  any  matters  related  to  the  projects;  (iii)  specify  the  qualification  and 
experience requirements for project management services; (iv) prepare cost estimates of the TA 
for project implementation; and (v) prepare a draft contract for hiring project management 
consultants. 
 
C.  Output and Reporting Requirements 
 
10.  The consultant shall prepare and submit the inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports.  
 
(i)  The inception report will be submitted within 1 month after mobilization. The 
report will cover the approach and methodology of works, detailed workflow, 
staffing schedule, and schedule of deliverables. 
 
(ii)  The  interim  report  will  be  submitted  at  the  end  of  month  3  after  the 
commencement of services. The report will present the work progress, issues 
identified, strategic approach recommended, outline design of the systems, and 
future direction of the work. 
 
(iii)  The  draft  final  report  will  be  submitted  at  the  end  of  month  5  after  the 
commencement of services. The report will comprise (a) all the findings and 
recommendations for system implementation, and (b) the complete set of tender 
documents and cost estimates. 
 
(iv)  The final report will be submitted within 1 month after receiving the comments on 
the draft final report. The report will address the comments made by MGU, other 
relevant agencies and stakeholders, and ADB. 
 
11.  The project team will summarize innovative technical, financial, and managerial solutions, 
processes,  and  results  of  the  ICC  ticketing  and  AVL  system  design  and  installation  in  a 
technical note. The technical note will be presented during workshops to the government and 
other project stakeholders.   
 
D.  Training, Workshops, and Technical Note 
 
12.  Three training sessions and workshops will be held during the course of the consulting 
services. The first workshop will be held in the end of the first month of services. The main 
objectives of the workshop will be the presentation of the inception report that will include the TA 
approach, methodology, and workflow of the consulting services. Basic information on the ICC 
ticketing system and the AVL systems (such as system description, configuration, functions, 
benefits, rough cost, and examples of other cities) will also be presented. 
 
13.  The  second  workshop  will  be  held  after  the  submission  of  the  interim  report.  The 
progress of the works will be reported, issues identified will be presented, and policy options will 
be discussed with relevant agencies and stakeholders. The progress of the system design will 
also be presented. The third workshop will be held upon submission of the draft final report. The

Appendix 3  13 
workshop will present and explain the outline of the system, the implementation program, and 
recommended measures necessary for system implementation.  
 
14.  The team leader will prepare a technical note that will (i) describe the main problems, 
challenges,  and  tasks  of  the  TA;  and  (ii)  summarize  technical,  financial,  and  managerial 
solutions developed during TA implementation. The consultant will provide training to MGU staff 
in the areas of information and communication technology (ICT) in public transport management 
and services.  
 
E.  Project Schedule 
 
15.  The TA will start on 1 September 2010 and will be completed on 28 February 2011. The 
draft final report will be submitted by the end of month 5 after TA commencement. 
 
F.  Consulting Services Inputs 
 
16.  The TA will recruit the following international consultants (15 person-months in total): 
 
(i)  ICT engineer and team leader (4 person-months), 
(ii)  ICC ticketing specialist (4 person-months), 
(iii)  AVL system specialist (3 person-months), 
(iv)  financial management specialist (3 person-months), and 
(v)  procurement specialist (1 person-month). 
 
17.  The TA will recruit the following national consultants (30 person-months in total): 
 
(i)  public transport specialist and deputy team leader (6 person-months), 
(ii)  ICT engineer and ICC ticketing systems specialist (6 person-months), 
(iii)  ICT engineer and AVL and GPS systems specialist (6 person-months), 
(iv)  financial management specialist (6 person-months), and 
(v)  financial and cost accounting specialist (6 person-months).
